abstract.p: Management reorganization undertaken at Merrill Lynch by E Stanley O'Neal, three months after he took over firm's brokerage operations, discussed; one of changes involved his naming James Gorman, nonbroker like himself, to be No. 2 executive; another was O'Neal's grouping together of all of Merrill's direct dealings with customers; he has also renamed brokerage network the advisory business to emphasize that the firm's main business is to provide financial service; O'Neal photo (M)

block.p: Three months after taking over Merrill Lynch & Company's brokerage operations, E. Stanley O'Neal has shaken up its management team, bringing in a deputy who put the bull back in the firm's advertising.

Mr. O'Neal, the first person not a stockbroker to run the nation's largest brokerage network, has named another nonbroker, James Gorman, to be the No. 2 executive, people inside the firm said. He also moved a few executives out of top jobs and promoted several others as part of a reorganization of the unit, those people said.

Three months after taking over Merrill Lynch & Company's brokerage operations, E. Stanley O'Neal has shaken up its management team, bringing in a deputy who put the bull back in the firm's advertising.

Mr. O'Neal, the first person not a stockbroker to run the nation's largest brokerage network, has named another nonbroker, James Gorman, to be the No. 2 executive, people inside the firm said. He also moved a few executives out of top jobs and promoted several others as part of a reorganization of the unit, those people said.
A Merrill spokesman declined to discuss the changes because they had not been announced to the firm's brokers.

The changes were anxiously anticipated by Merrill's 14,200 brokers, who knew little about Mr. O'Neal when he was promoted from chief financial officer to succeed John L. Steffens, the longtime head of the firm's brokerage business, in February. As Mr. O'Neal made the rounds, meeting managers and top brokers around the country, rumors swirled about how he might reshuffle the troops.

So far, the biggest surprise is the luring of Mr. Gorman, a former consultant with McKinsey & Company, who has been Merrill's chief marketing officer. Mr. Gorman essentially will serve as the chief operating officer of the brokerage operations and would be next in line for Mr. O'Neal's job, said a person who knows him.

Mr. O'Neal, 48, is widely viewed within the firm as most likely to succeed David H. Komansky as Merrill's chief executive. If that happens soon, Mr. O'Neal could be the first African-American chief executive of a major Wall Street firm. Mr. Komansky, who, like his predecessors, worked his way up through the broker ranks, is scheduled to retire in four years.

Like Mr. O'Neal, Mr. Gorman is highly regarded in Merrill's boardroom. Most recently, he engineered an alliance between Merrill and HSBC Holdings, a London-based banking company, to set up online banking services in several countries in Europe and Asia. Before that, he revamped Merrill's brand marketing, putting the bull and the image of bullishness back into Merrill's ads after a hiatus of several years.

As part of the reorganization, Mr. O'Neal is grouping together all of Merrill's direct dealings with customers, ranging from individual investors to owners of small businesses to pension plans. He is also renaming the brokerage network, now known as national sales, the advisory business to emphasize that the firm's main service is to provide financial advice, not to sell stocks and bonds. People who know them say that Mr. O'Neal and Mr. Gorman believe that the quality of service will be more important than sales skills.

Among other management changes, Mr. O'Neal picked four national sales directors, each with responsibility for an aspect of the brokerage business. One of the four, Jim Shoaf, already was a national sales director, overseeing the western half of the country. His counterpart, Robert Sherman, who oversaw the eastern half, is retiring.

The other three will be Robert Dineen, who had been managing Merrill's brokerage operations in New York City; Robert Mulholland, who had managed brokerage operations in New Jersey; and Michael Vorst, who managed operations in Southern California.

To make room for them, three executives are taking new jobs elsewhere in the firm. Madeline Weinstein, a senior vice president who was the highest-ranking woman in the brokerage operation, will move into corporate headquarters to take on some of Mr. Gorman's duties as director for corporate marketing. Allen Jones, also a senior vice president, will work with wealthy clients who need trusts and other wealth-management plans. A third executive had yet to be reassigned.
People inside the firm said that Mr. O'Neal had no plans to make other changes among managers in the brokerage network.
